TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national of NORP origins who was born in DATE and lives in GPE in GPE . She was represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

In DATE the applicant ’s husband entered NORP territory , where he unsuccessfully lodged an asylum request . Following her husband ’s departure , the applicant had been visited several times by NORP security officers who interrogated her about her husband ’s whereabouts . In DATE , NORP soldiers took her to a military station and raped her . This became known to the applicant ’s family and to the whole village . Following this incident , the applicant suffered a post - traumatic stress disorder ( PTSD , posttraumatische PERSON ) and considered suicide .

On DATE the applicant , together with her CARDINAL children , born in DATE and DATE , travelled by plane from GPE to GPE in GPE . She had been assisted by her father and other relatives , who had helped her to obtain false passports .

On DATE the applicant lodged an asylum request with ORG ( ORG für die ORG ) . She alleged that she had been persecuted because of her husband ’s activities in support of the NORP separatist movement . She further submitted that men from her village had urged her father to kill her in order to restore the honour of her family .
Later on the applicant submitted a medical report from her attending physician PERSON dated DATE , who drew the following conclusions :

“ According to our ... examinations , PERSON suffers from symptoms of anguish and a depressive disorder with dissociative symptoms and somatic disorders based on a severe post - traumatic stress disorder following suppression , abuse , threats and rape in GPE .

In order to carry out psychotherapy , it is necessary to provide a stable environment , because the treatment of traumas necessitates security and stability . PERSON is in need of both psychological and psychotherapeutic treatment . An antidepressant medication ( Doxepin QUANTITY mg ) has been started . The psychotherapy will last approximately DATE . A continuing treatment with supportive conversations is necessary in order to stabilise her mental condition and to avoid an aggravation .
In case of lack or interruption of treatment there is the risk of an aggravation of the illness , a decompensation of the condition , or suicide .

An escalation of her situation with respect to her right to stay would very probably lead to an aggraviation of PERSON clinical symptoms and thus to a mental decompensation and suicidal tendencies ( PERSON aufenthaltsrechtlichen FAC aktuellen Situation ist eine weitere Verschärfung der klinischen PERSON und damit eine psychische GPE suizidalen PERSON als extrem wahrscheinlich einzuschätzen ) .
In case of an expulsion to GPE , it has to be assumed that she could carry out her suicide thoughts and the expulsion to GPE has to be regarded as a re - traumatisation . ”
In DATE the applicant was temporarily hospitalised in a psychiatric clinic .
On DATE the applicant submitted further medical attestations according to which her situation had aggravated .

On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s asylum request , ordered the applicant to leave the NORP territory within DATE and announced expulsion in case of non - compliance . They found that the applicant had failed to establish that her rape had been politically motivated . According to ORG , there was no concrete risk that the applicant would , once again , be abused on her return to GPE . With respect to the alleged risk to be killed by family members in order to restore the family ’s honour , the ORG noted that ORG prosecuted so - called “ crimes of honour ” and that there existed the possibility to obtain protection in women ’s refuges . Furthermore , the ORG did not attach much credence to the applicant ’s submissions relating to the risk of persecution by her family .

Referring to a report by ORG dated DATE and to a further report dated DATE , ORG further found that the necessary medical treatment for the applicant ’s illness was available in all major psychiatric clinics , such as the university clinics in GPE and GPE and the public hospital in GPE . According to ORG , these clinics applied internationally approved diagnostic standards and offered the same therapeutic concepts which were common in LOC . In case of need , it was possible to obtain free medical treatment with the so called “ green card ” . This did also apply in case of a possible retraumatisation .

ORG further found that it was not competent to examine if the applicant ’s deportation as such could lead to suicide attempts , as this primarily concerned the question of the feasibility of deportation .

The applicant , represented by counsel , lodged a motion with ORG ( Verwaltungsgericht ) . She argued , inter alia , that the necessary medical treatment was not available in practice . In support of her allegations , she submitted a report by ORG in GPE on the medical care provided for persons with mental illnesses dated DATE . This report noted , inter alia , that care for mentally ill patients was provided for in the major cities and provincial centres of GPE . On the other hand , there was a lack of possibilities of long - term treatments for adult patients .
The last paragraph of the report reads as follows :

“ ORG there are CARDINAL hospitals in CARDINAL towns which are entitled to issue medical attestation for handicapped and/or mentally ill persons ... It follows that there is not in every province the possibility to obtain specialist medical treatment .

CARDINAL of the most serious problems is the almost complete hopelessness ( “ fast völlige Ausweglosigkeit ” ) of certain groups of patients – in particular adults – to obtain adequate treatment : this concerns traumatised persons , raped women , persons suffering from anguish traumas , highly suicidal persons , to name but a few . The local ORG confirmed that while the purely medical care of handicapped or mentally ill people could be provided , it was generally ( in der PERSON ) impossible to offer continuing therapy for lack of professional and financial resources . It is not possible to continue therapies for patients returning from GPE or the GPE , as follows already from the different therapeutic concepts of these countries . ”

The applicant further alleged that her return to GPE would , with a high probability , lead to her re - traumatisation , which would eventually endanger her life . She submitted a further medical report by PERSON dated DATE , which reads as follows :

“ I am treating PERSON since DATE . PERSON is a severely traumatised person , who suffers from typical disturbances caused by a posttraumatic stress disorder ( ORG CARDINAL ORG ) with extreme nervousness and attacks of fear and panic .

PERSON is regularly treated with supportive conversations which take place at ORG intervals . Additionally , she is treated with antidepressant medication , currently with QUANTITY GPE per day . The patient ’s state of health has further deteriorated . She increasingly complains about insomnia and gives credible accounts of suicidal thoughts . She reports about the escalation of her situation with respect to her right to stay . This scares her additionally . She suffers from serious losses of self - esteem .
On the basis of DATE ’s conversation , a further aggravation of her clinical symptoms and thus a mental decompensation with suicidal behaviour has to be regarded as being extremely likely . ”

On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s motion . That court found that the applicant had neither a right to asylum as guaranteed by LAW , nor was she protected from expulsion as a political refugee pursuant to LAW , see relevant domestic law below ) . ORG accepted the applicant ’s submissions that she had been raped and subsequently suffered from a post - traumatic disorder . It further assumed that the applicant ’s persecution had been politically motivated . While the applicant had failed to establish that she herself or her husband had been persecuted as suspects of supporting the NORP separatist movement , the ORG accepted that the applicant ’s rape may have been related to her NORP origins .

However , the applicant did not risk further persecution , as she would be safe if she travelled to the Western part of GPE ( inländische ORG ) . As neither the applicant nor her husband could be regarded as being suspected of separatist activities , there was no indication that the security forces would persecute her there . ORG further found that the applicant had not established that she risked falling victim to a “ crime of honour ” in the NORP part of GPE , taking into account that her father had helped her to escape to GPE .

ORG further found that there was no impediment to the expulsion under LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW for lack of a serious and concrete risk for her life or physical integrity . According to consistent reports ( nach ständiger ORG ) , there was a possibility to treat mental illnesses in GPE . Referring to a judgment of ORG and considering all material in its possession , ORG followed this assessment . It found , in particular , that the applicant was not restricted to seek medical treatment in her home region , but could also be expected to expand her search into her further environment and into LOC . The applicant had not established that her illness could not be treated in LOC .

ORG finally considered that the possibility of a retraumatisation could in principle constitute an impediment to expulsion . According to ORG , however , it could not be deduced from the medical attestations submitted by the applicant that this applied to the applicant for the time being . It found that in the report dated DATE Dr PERSON indicated that the applicant ’s deportation as such might aggravate her medical condition . This might lead to an impediment to deportation relating to NORP territory ( inlandsbezogenes PERSON ) , but not to a danger in the receiving country ( zielstaatsbezogenes PERSON ) . In his more recent medical attestation dated DATE , PERSON more generally stated that a further aggravation of her clinical symptoms and thus a mental decompensation with suicidal behaviour had to be regarded as being extremely likely . This indicated that the aggravation of the applicant ’s illness was independent from her return to GPE . ORG finally found that the other medical attestations submitted by the applicant did not lead to other conclusions .

The question if the applicant ’s deportation as such would cause a danger to her health had to be examined separately by the local ORG Ausländerbehörde ) . ORG further noted that the applicant could seek ORG and ORG assistance in finding the necessary health facilities .

On DATE the applicant lodged a request to be granted leave to appeal . She alleged , in particular , that ORG had failed to consider the report of ORG of DATE which , according to the applicant , raised serious doubts if her illness could be treated in GPE . She further complained that ORG had failed to consider her submissions with respect to the risk of retraumatisation .

On DATE the GPE Court of Appeal ( Oberverwaltungsgericht ) refused the applicant ’s request . It found , in particular , that ORG had duly examined the possibility to obtain medical treatment in GPE . It noted that ORG had found that the applicant was not restricted to her home area , but could be expected to search medical care in LOC . Under these circumstances , ORG did not have to refer explicitly to the NORP Consulate ’s report . ORG further found that ORG had duly considered the expert reports on the applicant ’s state of health .

On DATE the applicant , represented by counsel , lodged a constitutional complaint . She alleged that the administrative courts had violated her right to a fair hearing and her right to asylum as guaranteed by LAW . She complained , in particular , that ORG had failed to duly consider the fact that the applicant , according to the medical report dated DATE , risked re - traumatisation on her return to GPE . She further complained that ORG had failed to hear expert opinion on the risk of re - traumatisation .
On DATE ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) refused to entertain the applicant ’s complaint .

The applicant , her husband and children subsequently lodged a request with the North Rhine - Westphalia Commission for ORG ) . No decision has yet been given . These proceedings do not have a suspensive effect ; the ORG ’s recommendations are not binding on the domestic authorities .

By order of CARDINAL DATE ORG ( Amtsgericht ) placed the applicant into a psychiatric hospital . ORG found a strong indication that the applicant suffered from a psychotic disorder which necessitated treatment and which could pose a danger to her life or integrity . According to a medical report of DATE , she had recently been suicidal . ORG further ordered the preparation of an expert opinion on the applicant ’s state of health .
Article CARDINAL ) of the NORP Basic Law ( Grundgesetz ) provides that persons persecuted on political grounds enjoy the right of asylum .
Section CARDINAL of LAW – as in force at the relevant time – prohibits the deportation of aliens to a state where they would face political persecution .

Section CARDINAL prohibits deportation into a state where the alien faces a serious risk of being subjected to torture . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW further prohibits any expulsion which would be contrary to the provisions of the LAW .

If the preconditions for the application of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) are not met , protection may be granted under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , which grants a discretion to the authorities to suspend deportation in case of a substantial danger for life , personal integrity or liberty of an alien .

According to the case - law of ORG ) ORG , during asylum proceedings , only examines if the alien would be in danger in the receiving country ( zielstaatsbezogene Abschiebungshindernisse ) . Other impediments to deportation , which could arise on NORP territory ( inlandsbezogene NORP ) have to be examined in separate proceedings by the local ORG .
